factoid: Bolkónski inquired, “Is that so? And what did he say?”
Dolgorúkov replied, “What can he say? Tra-di-ri-di-ra and so on… merely to gain time.”
Dolgorúkov told Bolkónski that he is in our hands, that’s certain.
Dolgorúkov said that what was most amusing was that we could not think how to address the reply.
Dolgorúkov said that if not as ‘Consul’ and not as ‘Emperor’, it should be to ‘General Bonaparte.’
Bolkónski remarked that between not recognizing the Emperor as Emperor and calling him General Bonaparte, there is a difference.
Dolgorúkov interrupted and laughed, saying, “That’s just it.”
Dolgorúkov said that Bilíbin suggested addressing the Emperor as ‘Usurper and Enemy of Mankind.’
Dolgorúkov said that Bilíbin found a suitable form for the address.
Dolgorúkov said that Bilíbin is a wise and clever fellow.
Dolgorúkov said that the address was to the Head of the French Government, “Au chef du gouvernement français.”
Bolkónski said that the Emperor will dislike the address extremely.
Dolgorúkov said that his brother knows the Emperor, who has dined with him more than once in Paris, and tells him he never met a more cunning or subtle diplomatist.
Dolgorúkov said that the Emperor is a combination of French adroitness and Italian play-acting.
Dolgorúkov said that Count Markóv was the only man who knew how to handle the Emperor.
Dolgorúkov told the story of the handkerchief, saying that it is delightful.
Dolgorúkov told how Bonaparte wished to test Count Markóv, the ambassador, and dropped a handkerchief in front of him.
Dolgorúkov told how Count Markóv immediately dropped his own handkerchief beside it and picked it up without touching Bonaparte’s.
Bolkónski said “Delightful!” and that he has come as a petitioner on behalf of this young man.
An aide-de-camp came in to summon Dolgorúkov to the Emperor.
Dolgorúkov said, “What a nuisance,” and pressed the hands of Prince Andrew and Borís.
Dolgorúkov said he should be very glad to do all in his power both for Prince Andrew and for this dear young man.
Dolgorúkov pressed the hand of the young man with good-natured, sincere, and animated levity.
Dolgorúkov said, “But you see... another time!”
Borís was excited by the thought of being so close to the higher powers.

Borís felt himself to be at that moment in contact with the springs that set in motion the enormous movements of the mass of which in his regiment he felt himself a tiny, obedient, and insignificant atom.
They followed Prince Dolgorúkov out into the corridor and met a short man in civilian clothes with a clever face and sharply projecting jaw.
The short man nodded to Dolgorúkov as to an intimate friend and stared at Prince Andrew with cool intensity.
The short man walked straight toward Prince Andrew and evidently expected him to bow or to step out of his way.
Prince Andrew did neither.
A look of animosity appeared on Prince Andrew’s face.
The short man turned away and went down the side of the corridor.
Borís asked, “Who was that?”
Bolkónski said that the short man was one of the most remarkable, but to him most unpleasant of men, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Prince Adam Czartorýski.
Bolkónski added that such men as Prince Adam Czartorýski decide the fate of nations.
The next day the army began its campaign.
Up to the very battle of Austerlitz, Borís was unable to see either Prince Andrew or Dolgorúkov again.
Borís remained for a while with the Ismáylov regiment.
